column1: Eye muscle repair is surgery to correct eye muscle problems that cause strabismus (crossed eyes).
However, adults who have similar eye problems may also have it done.
- To strengthen a muscle, a section of the muscle or tendon may be removed to make it shorter.
Strabismus is a disorder in which the two eyes do not line up in the same direction.
Surgery may be recommended when strabismus does not improve with glasses or eye exercises.

Risks for any anesthesia are: - Reactions to anesthesia medicines - Breathing problems Risks for any surgery are: - Bleeding - Infection Some risks for this surgery include: - Wound infections - Damage to the eye (rare) - Permanent double vision (rare)

Your child's eye surgeon may ask for: - A complete medical history and physical exam before the procedure - Orthoptic measurements (eye movement measurements) Always tell your child's doctor or nurse: - What drugs your child is taking - Include any drugs, herbs, or vitamins you bought without a prescription - About any allergies your child may have to any medicines, latex, tape, soaps or skin cleaners During the days before the surgery: - About 10 days before the surgery, you may be asked to stop giving your child aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), warfarin (Coumadin), and any other blood thinners.
- The doctor will make sure your child is healthy enough for surgery and does not have any signs of illness.
